response.answer_text: Freud writes about two kinds of fear; one is real (both rational and suggestive of an actual threat) and the other is irrational and neurotic in nature — based entirely upon an imaginary threat. When white people express race-based hatred for people of color, it stems from a neurotic fear. When people of color develop race-based hatred for white people, it is based upon a real fear that comes from historical, political, legal, and social marginalization. The former constitutes racism and the latter involves some sort of self-preservation or cautionary posturing because of a real danger created by racial formations. Now, in answer to your first question as to why someone becomes racist, I think it starts out as a reactionary identity formation and later becomes manifest as an irrational fear of losing power. I also think the desire to inflict incessant and gratuitous humiliation upon an other because of the color of their skin can only be the result of a deep wound — some kind of insecurity that attaches itself with a psychosexual sadism. To your second question about how, I’d say it happens most effectively through historical, philosophic, scientific, legal, and economic spheres that have rationalized what ought to be considered irrational: racial prejudice. What’s scary about racism is that it is often unrecognized as such, unquestioned when it occurs, and highly convenient for those looking for someone to blame when the chips are down. You can be literally destroyed by what people think about you and the widespread mistreatment of people of color in the U.S. is a stain on the fabric of this great nation. A little history lesson could be useful here. At the same time that the first African slave was forcibly removed and brought to the shores of North America in 1619, Europeans were wondering if the Native Americans were indeed human beings with redeemable souls. In the late 17th century, when the original source of unpaid labor was performed by European indentured servants, they slowly started to win rights and entitlements as they were being replaced by African slaves on new tobacco plantations in Virginia and Maryland. By the time we get to the 1790 Naturalization Act, which permitted only "free white persons" to become naturalized citizens, the doors were wide open for European immigrants. It’s also worth remembering that only citizens could vote, serve on juries, hold office, and in some cases, even hold property. In fact, racial barriers to naturalized U.S. citizenship weren't removed until the McCarran-Walter Act in 1952, and white racial preferences in immigration remained (officially so) until 1965. Following the 1790 Naturalization Act, there was also the 1830 Indian Removal Act, which forcibly relocated Indian tribes to west of the Mississippi River to make room for white settlers. Citing the inferiority of Blacks and Indians was an easy way to justify racism. There are so many more examples in-between, but the next big one was the 1862 Homestead Act that gave away 270 million acres (10% of the total land area of the United States) of what had initially been Indian Territory. This land was converted to private hands, overwhelmingly white. When American slavery finally ended, the federal government never followed through on General Sherman's Civil War plan to divide up plantations and give each freed slave "40 acres and a mule." The only monetary compensation that was made was in Washington, D.C. where the government paid up to $300 per slave upon emancipation - not to the slaves, of course — but to local slaveholders as compensation for a loss of property. The legacy of slavery lived on not only in the impoverished conditions for Black people but in the wealth and prosperity that white slaveowners and their descendents were afforded. Economists who try to place a dollar value on how much white Americans have profited from 200 years of unpaid slave labor, including interest, start their estimates at $1 trillion. Once we get to the 20th century, Alien Land Laws were passed in California and other states, reserving farm land for white growers by preventing Asian immigrants (who were ineligible to become citizens) from owning or leasing land. There is a widespread temptation to see race as either essence or illusion and neither really deals with the social, political and economic consequences of racial formations. Race is a socially constructed phenomenon, but that does not make it any less real. We are still deeply affected by racial tensions and those are exacerbated by gross income inequality. We are facing a serious threat right now — a kind of mild, pernicious apartheid. I am not sure how many people can really see it, but we all feel it, and the lines are being drawn by white supremacists. Understanding what racism is and how one becomes racist is of the utmost importance.

I am going to disagree with most of the people here, but with a theory that should make more sense to people. In fact, it’s not likely that parents are at fault. These are the following steps for a child to become racist. The child become self-aware. Within the family, they learn to recognise and become familiar with the faces around them. Humans are adept at facial recognition and will subconsciously learn the process.The child experiences other people. The child notices that some people do not look like others, in that one particular feature overwhelms the more subtle facial recognition processes. A highly noticeable difference in skin colour would be the main feature noticed, however it could also be eye or face shape shape. Children will also notice obesity, homelessness, beauty, warts, tattoos and many other physical factors. If the community is very uniform in appearance, this step could be delayed, or it could be that only minor differences mark a person as different, such as very curly hair in a community with straight hair. Depending on level of diversity community, the child will create a memory model of the types of people they encounter. Adults can easily access these memory spaces: if I ask you to imagine an Chinese man or a European woman, you’ll instantly access these childhood models. Furthermore, if I ask you to imagine a Cologhlis and you don’t know where in Africa they are, you may access a generalised African image.The child experiences their community, town or city. They are going to notice that how people group together, how they relate to each other, how they speak, who is given authority and who seems to be out of place. They will get a sense of whom to fear and whom to trust. Adults will provide a range of clues about this from overt explanations good and bad, to body language and voice tone. Threatening and other negative personal experiences with people who match a group type will create strong neural pathways. Importantly children will also discuss among themselves, especially when they start to interact at school and decide who is a leader and who gets to be teased.The child attempts to assemble a worldview. Armed with these experiences plus what they’ve learnt from others, from school and the media, the child assembles the jigsaw puzzle of how people around the world are constituted. They won’t be able to avoid learning that dark skinned people are from Africa, and that light skinned people are from Europe. They may get different senses of how Asia, the Americas or Oceania is organised. The less experience the child has, the more abstract is their impression. Hence if there are many Vietnamese in the child’s community, they will represent Asians generally. If there are Indians, then they may represent Asia, or the child may differentiate into two or more groups. This is a complex and important problem, and the child will solve it dynamically and continuously.The child incorporates their moral view into their worldview. The child will begin to be told about their own role in the community, and their future contribution to it. The child will become aware of how the community organises itself, and their own responsibilities when dealing with other people. The community could be egalitarian, separated or homogeneous, some other description or hybrid, and the child will need to fit in with that or rebel against it. When dealing with a certain type of person, the child will want to know what to expect and how to avoid being in trouble. Questions will need to be answers: how to communicate? What customs should you follow? What is offensive to them? What role must take in practice for becoming adult? Who earns my national or cultural loyalty? How to I maintain my self-worth and confidence in the face of this complexity?The child takes a position on racialism. As people do not come with instruction labels, the obvious solution to an incomplete problem is to reconcile the cultural factors with how a person presents themselves visually, and those early experiences of fear and comfort. It is then inevitable that the child will learn that seemingly most people conveniently divide humanity into three to seven racial groups, and in many communities there’s a degree of consistency. For example, the United States has two main groups, called “black”/”people of color” and “white”, and then there’s four less commonly discussed, but consistently listed groups of Hispanic, Asian, Native American, Pacific Islanders. This is an authoritative solution for that country, never mind multi-racial people or having an ethnicity not quite in one group or the other. In other countries, a three-race model is commonplace, while other countries actively educate against all racialism. The child however may pick up an old book or look up Wikipedia and pick up an old anthropological scheme. If the child is scientifically-minded or aware of multi-racialism, they may comprehend the idea that humans vary by only small degrees, and no racial scheme can satisfy objective criteria - in which case they reject racialism and deal directly with complexity.The final step to being racist is to promote racialism as a primary method of assembling their worldview and assessing the people they encounter. Experiences with people, the understanding of the news, national identity and political positions are slotted into racial categories, which then leads to making broad assessments. These can even become self-reinforcing, such that every negative fact about an individual, community or country is evidence in support of the worldview. The person’s own identity is re-enforced positively or negatively depending on their disposition. Note that there’s different types of attachment to racism, for example a person may not be hateful. They just withdraw or may even be paternalistic. Poorly-handled, even diversity training can backfire and promote racism, where a strongly racialist position is pushed or assumed.In my view, the easiest way out of this process is to understand that racism is not just an evil, but it’s flawed and impractical. The scientific descriptions of humanity have long established this. As an adult, we could understand the humanity is far more diverse than we can imagine or experience. We’d be unwise to make assumptions about people in parts of the world we haven’t been. There are billions of varying face shapes, body types and skin colours. The people we meet are visually far more unique, than what we see at first glance. Importantly, when a person acts good or bad, this comes from their unique character, not their surface appearance. Finally, there is the humility in knowing we can never fully understand all of humanity.

Question: Why and how does a person become racist? I don’t feel as though I am fully qualified to answer this question as I myself am no specialist in psychology or sociology. I am, rather, a political science student, so I do end up learning a bit about racial conflicts within my university classes. Outside of university, I’ve also read some books on racial conflicts that tend to be written by sociologists wishing to make some avocation among society. But even then, I will not claim to be some specialist and will not pretend that I am one. However, I was requested by Tom Robinson, an individual I would consider a friend on Quora, to answer this question, so I will gladly oblige. From the literature I have read, it seems as though people who are openly racist share one quality: a lack of wealth. In fact, according to this study (Source: Economic scarcity alters the perception of race), falling on hard times can end up making people more racist. In general, this makes sense. We, as individuals, do not tend to like taking full accountability for our failures. We do not like thinking that it is our own faults for our failing economic conditions. As such, we may likely end up searching for scapegoats for our failures. In this case, could end up being race. Furthermore, with a lack of wealth comes a lack of education for many people. This means that the horizons of certain people are limited due to a lack of interacting with other people and they grow up in a relatively closed community. Hence, these individuals grow up with narrow perceptions of various issues around the world, including race relations. Another factor seems to be religion, particularly incredibly evangelical ones (Source: Religious People Tend to Be More Racist, Study Finds). Now. I’m going to be extremely clear here: I am not saying that being religious implies that you are racist. Rather, I am implying that individuals who tend to be racist also happen to be religious. In general, this can, in fact, make sense. Many religions, particularly extremely evangelical ones, create an ‘us vs them’ mentality, essentially committing the False Dilemma, otherwise known as the ‘either/or fallacy.’ Essentially, this dilemma is created when outsiders of one group is perceived by another group to be the ideological enemy. A prime example of this tactic can be seen in the hysteria that was the debate about our response to the September 11th terrorist attack. “Either you are with us Americans, or you are against us and work with the terrorists,” was a very common mantra held by many public figures as well as the general public. Essentially, this dilemma attempts to create an imaginary, singular enemy that one side can combat. It is an attempt to dishonestly and incorrectly over-simplify issues. In the case of incredibly evangelical belief systems, they could create false dilemma’s with virtually everyone else in the world different from them. And nothing is more easy to see as a difference than skin color. They could, in fact, attempt to justify the demonetization of other groups of people by race through some kind of religious text justification, typically one which most religious people at large will either disregard or not know the existence of. However, the main reason I feel as though racism remains pertinent in the United States is simply because of the way people are raised. And I do not believe that children are raised intentionally to perceive their race or group as superior to others. Rather, I feel as though one of two things could lead to many children developing racist tendencies. Firstly, there is an ongoing debate within psychology that asks the question or whether or not children are born racist or not. Now, by saying ‘born racist,’ I do not mean that children are born to hate other groups of people for their skin color. Rather, these undeveloped children could likely develop feelings of ‘us vs them’ that I explained prior as a kind of survival mechanism. It would be instinctual to perceive people different from their immediate group of peers as threats and, as such, develop disdain towards outsiders who are different. There are numerous articles and books written on this topic, but a good introductory source on this can be read here: Are Kids Racist?. This source, mind you, is not some incredibly conclusive study, but it is good introductory material in a topic that I myself cannot and will not claim to be an expert in, but find interesting myself. Another possibility in regards to children developing racist tendencies is societal influences on the children themselves in regards to how we raise them. Many articles are written on the topic of teaching children to be more race-conscious because as kids develop and do not themselves learn about racial diversity and how it’s natural, they could develop ideas within their own minds about race that are false. Over time, these ideas can take hold and make children themselves believe false ideas about other groups of people. It is not intentional by any means, but by not discussing racial differences with impressionable children, they could develop ideas that are not true in regards to race. Another article on that, which I personally think is far more detailed than the prior article, can be read here: Research-Based Advice on Teaching Children Not to Be Racist. So, what does all the information conveyed thus far lead to? Well, as with plenty of other subjects, the origin of racist thoughts in individuals is incredibly complicated. There are an endless myriad of influences on children and adults that can make them have more racist tendencies. Largely, I believe it is a mix of all three of these reasons, albeit the second one is, in my opinion, less significant of an influence on people. Rather, I believe that the lack of wealth and education, combined with impressionable children being taught non-deliberately to hold false views on different groups of people can lead to racism. The two of these combined may seem, in fact, to be an extremely potent force for racism. Allow me to explain. Imagine you raise a child from birth to adulthood. The child is either immediately born with ideas of ‘us vs them’ in his/her head, as might be natural among all humans first developing, and is never provided a discussion by the parent on race issues or never has his/her questions on race at a young age answered properly. Or perhaps the child just develops his/her often false ideas about people of different races. Either way, the child has a false perception of others based on their race that, itself, is likely benign in nature. As such, the child immediately develops feelings that are false of other groups of people from the beginning. Next, imagine that you raise that child in a poor household and that said child does not end up getting a good education. Now, perhaps this lifestyle of being poor is by no means your or anyone else’s fault, it’s just capitalism in play. Well, that child is now growing up in an environment where he/she is likely to not receive a good education on issues and, thus, will likely not broaden his/her horizons, and may end up becoming resentful of others in general. Combine this feelings of resentment and this relatively ignorant mind (again, the ignorance is the fault of nobody but the conditions the child grew up in) with the false ideas he/she grew up believing about race, and you basically end up with racism. Now, will this child grow up to become a Ku Klux Klansman? Likely not. However, that child him/herself will end up resenting other groups of people, perhaps holding incredibly false views of these other groups and their behaviors, and then said child will likely have children and the cycle will begin all over again. Perhaps those children may end up becoming racist too due to either the racist feelings of the parent being passed down unintentionally (or, if the parent is openly racist, intentionally) or due to the parent simply never talking of the issue. The cycle simply continues after that. Thankfully, we live in a far more educated world than once before. Topics of race are now on the forefront and new studies in psychology and sociology are tackling questions of race more than ever before. More people around the world are also receiving better education than was previously available to them. As such, I believe we are on our way into making the world a less racially hostile place to live in, and that is a sign of progress in my opinion. Racism and issues of race will probably never disappear, but I hope that they will become less relevant as more people are better educated in the future.

Humans are tribalistic. Virtually all humans. I spent (emphasis on the past tense) a long time thinking that those who weren’t liberal were idiots or monsters—along the lines of “basket of deplorables”. Then there was a while where I thought (again, past tense) any non-Libertarians were irrational and inconsistent (actually, most political ideologies are, but I admit that my own views are not self-consistent at that level; they are consistent with my underlying reasoning but that in turn draws on arbitrary premises). Anyway, my point is, I’m not just saying, vaguely, that people are tribalistic. I’m tribalistic; it takes constant vigilance to overcome those tendencies, I can’t be certain I’m succeeding, and I know that if I let my vigilance slip I go back to it. (Relatively recently, in irrationality induced by concern for a friend threatened by the belief I am about to refer to, I stated—and once again, I do not currently believe this—that those who believe apostates should be killed [believe, not act on it] should be denied immigration to the United States. Remind you of a certain political figure? Had to calm down before I remembered that I consider it invariably wrong to deny such things on the basis of belief.) Humans care about those who are in our tribe, whatever that means (political ideology, nationality, religion… skin color, perhaps?), and we don’t care about people who aren’t, and indeed often hate them. (This makes it very important to those who would avoid this tendency to remember the principle of cosmopolitanism: we are all citizens of the world, all the same tribe). So take, for example, a white person who is surrounded by white people for their entire life (also works with a black person surrounded by black people, a Muslim surrounded by Muslims, a straight person surrounded by straight people, etc). White people are their tribe—they have never learned to think of black people as equally important, and they will protect their own first. Now suppose that somebody has something to gain from a division and they say that black people are criminals, a threat. What reason does the person have to doubt this? They will want to protect their own against the enemy. And there you have it. A racist. Many people may not be racists, but I can guarantee you that, unless you take an incredible effort to avoid it, you [the reader] think the same way about something. You have a tribe, even if it’s not dictated by skin color, religion, nationality, or sexual orientation.

I’m going to make an embarassing confession: I started to feel racist after moving to France and had to work on my way of thinking to stop it. I wasn’t brought up to be racist. I had friends who came from different ethnic groups and didn’t think much about it. When I moved to France, I could not, at first, tell if someone was of North African heritage or not, but I rapidly learned to both identify and to fear men and boys who looked North African. I had horrible experiences every day. I was followed in the street, touched and insulted on public transport, even spat at, and the people doing this were of North African heritage. As a blonde, blue eyed woman wearing a skirt, they considered me to be a “pute”, which means whore. I rapidly learned the meaning of the word they shouted at me. I didn’t like the way they behaved, nor did I like the pattern of thinking I was falling into. I forced myself to think about what was happening and analyse my behaviour, my thinking, and also theirs. I couldn’t change them, but I made changes in myself. In their subculture, wearing a skirt above the knee (I never wore short skirts) was seen as provokation, so I started only wearing trousers. I stopped glaring at them when they made insulting remarks, but did what French women do, which is ignore them totally. I asked myself why they hated me, and realised that it was because they were totally marginalised. If they couldn’t get recognition in society, they at least felt superior to women. Now, I don’t think women are in any way inferior to men, and I don’t think men and boys should be allowed to dictate what women wear, but I needed to adapt to survive and to gain some empathy for the people around me. Next, I was lucky enough to get a job in higher education where I came into contact with plenty of people of North African heritage who were pleasant and kind, as well as friendly students from North Africa. I could counter racist sentiments in myself by thinking of them. I wonder if other people have had similar experiences to mine?

I had never knowingly met a gay person. I had, however, met a large number of people who seemed to know for a fact that gay people were evil and that their morals were despicable and that they were an abberation against God’s rational plan. But then I actually met some gay people and pretty much all of that nonsense flew straight out the window. Five years later I had gay friends and I even ended up with a gay roommate for a short time. To me, they seemed just like anybody else, except gay. One of the aphorisms that has stayed with me for most of life is something said by one of my personal heroes, Will Rogers. “I never met a man I didn’t like.” The reason he was able to like everybody was because he took the trouble to get to know them before he ever made any judgments about their character. The overwhelming vast majority of the people on this planet are driven by the same fears, concerns, likes and loves as everybody else is. It’s just that if you don’t get to know those people, then you are at the mercy of some other fool’s lack of knowledge about them.

Great question: Racism exploits a character flaw, one which is neither hereditary, nor learned, nor predictable. Character is as fundamental a mystery as consciousness, itself, because both are properties of the same—nevermind; you wouldn’t understand. Let’s move on. Racism tells to people who want to hear it, something that they should not want to believe: you are better than yourself. Yes, this is a contradiction—that’s why no one should want to believe it. In order to make it work, one must convince himself that his fellow man is not the same as him. This allows him to assume whatever relative position he desires—always “better.” Racism finds people in a number of ways. Some people are told by a parent(s) that they are better than whomever, for whatever reason. The reasons have changed to suit the needs of the day, but subsequent generations embrace the falsehood because it carries the weight of their parents influence. Others receive the nonsense from friends, associates, and school or workmates. With the advent of modern media and communications technologies, racism has a more effective, subtle and nearly untraceable means of disseminating. Like all words and ideas, it’s all about context. In general, we accept that a person is a racist if they have at least one of the three following traits: substantial and relatively overt fear of, hatred of, revulsion at or bias against a racial (or sometimes ethnic or religious group if that group is being thought of in fundamentally racial terms, which is why Islamophobia can be racist if the fear and hatred is colored by some kind of bias against the groups that are associated with Islam such as Persians and Arabs); an overt ideology of racial supremacy, separatisim or hatred based fundamentally in not only accepting the theoretical existence of racial categories but actually aiming to create policy from those categories; or a substantial covert or subconscious bias that effectively makes one virulently dilike another group. Racism requires the combination of two characteristics: a belief that there actually are distinct human biological subgroups that can be considered to be distinct “races” by some criterion, and ascribing a negative value claim to those differences. One could accept that blacks and whites in America are truly distinct groups with genetically non-trivial variation that might go beyond mere skin tone or specific disease inheritance and toward something more like a determinative subgroup, and still not be a racist if they felt that people living near each other of different groups still need not be a problem. At that point, they would be a racialist. Some people on the alt-left fulfill this criterion. These practical definitions go beyond most textbook definitions but they tend to encapsulate what most folks think of as what would constitute a racist. Of course, a person could be more or less racist by those definitions. There’s a big difference between a neo-Nazi and someone who knows that their biases are silly but still have them and can’t stop having a strong negative feeling. Of course, in practice, there are other contexts that we care about. For one, there’s the context of institutional racism. As Bob Blauner famously pointed out, different people relate to racism, and even how they think about it, differently. If I’m a police officer who may not have substantial overt biases or a racist ideology but I don’t do much to be a good professional in a system that tends to produce racist outcomes, I could be argued, in this institutional context, to be a racist, or at least acting in a way that produces a racist impact. I know this sounds harsh, and it is possible that the word “racist” may be too strong. But frankly, it doesn’t matter if a legislator chooses to introduce a bill that will slam black folks because he’s an overt bigot, or because he wants to court overt bigots in his constituency, or because there’s a powerful lobby that will make money off the bill, or just because he was lazy. What he didn’t do was care about how his behavior would impact a group of people. Another possibility would be when an activist says that “We’re all a little racist”. That’s, again, a harsh statement, but it could have value if we’re trying to communicate that we’re all quite likely to have biases and trying to encourage people to think that they may not be all that different from someone with substantial more overt biases. The problem is when we confuse the differences between institutional and individual racism, or subconscious and conscious racism. Calling something or someone “racist” in the wrong context, or even not being clear what context we are intending.
